SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A brief explanation to the effect:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada can give exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will be answered by all his experience or the pioneer life as he knew it. Others may not apply to anyone else. It is therefore necessary that each person should answer the questions according to his own experience.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether they are now living in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply a list of answers.

Clear Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did You Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: William Henry Brokenshire
2. Your address: Eastview, Saskatchewan
3. Date: Feb. 1954
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Cornwall, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Thomas Henry Brokenshire, farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): November 1902
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Worked at Gainsborough, Sask., from April 1897.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): Twenty-one years.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To find suitable work & try to make a home for my parents.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): C.P.R. was doing much advertising in England.

Brokenshire, William Henry
Estevan, Sask.

1. Your full name: William Henry Brokenshire
2. Your address: Estevan, Saskatchewan
3. Date: Feb. 19th (1954)
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Cornwall, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Thomas Henry Brokenshire
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): November 1902
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - From April 1897 at Fairbrother, Sask.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you could not have been "in my teens", etc.). Twenty-one years.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - To find suitable work
   - To make a home for my parents
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). L.P.R. was doing much advertising in England.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   With a family from my native village.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Railway to Liverpool, by C.P.R., Steamship to Halifax, N.S., C.P.R. Railway to Gainsborough, Sask.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Gainsborough, Sask. and later Estevan, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Estevan, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   Farm work. The same.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Farm work.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Not very frequently.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
    and place of marriage.
    am a bachelor.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place
    to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.
    My parents, two brothers, six sisters all came & settled here except one sister who worked & married in Manitoba.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your
    memory which you would like to record?
    Prairie fires would come & destroy haystacks etc.
    Rivers & creeks in flood sometimes took fodder.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church,
    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    Very little travelling was done before the automobile came.

Am a bachelor.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?  

22. In other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tall when they came and where they settled.  
My parents, two brothers, six sisters all came & settled here except one sister who worked & married in Manitoba.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?  
Prairie fires, world war & death by typhoid. River weeks in flood sometime took folder.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How far? By what means?  
Very little travelling was done before the automobile came.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1906

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Estevan, 4 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.). We still do our trading in Estevan, such as groceries & some wearing apparel.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? When necessary.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? About 1908

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Woodend Telephone Co., 1914.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Yes, we were satisfied to stay here & make a home.

Yes, we were grateful to stay here & make a home.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
Some went back to U.S.A. Winters were too severe & too many hardships.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
Yes, several families went to North Dakota.
